facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 294 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 294 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1958, of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Case No. 39 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1958, of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Case No. 39 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on April 27, 1962 by WANCHOOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOOO, J.-The short question raised in this appeal by special leave is whether it is possible to add up the value of more than one rural building, each of which is less than Rs.10,000/- or Rs.20,000/in order to reach the total of Rs. 10,000/- or Rs. 20,000/- for the purpose of taking the case for companypensation for rural buildings out of the ambit of r.65 of the Rules framed under the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act, 1954  44 of 1954   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: The respondent is a displaced person who migrated from what is number part of West Pakistan to India.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for this purpose are these. The respondent is a displaced person who migrated from what is number part of West Pakistan to India.

facts.text: The respondent had agricultural land as well as houses in the rural area in the place from where he migrated.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that he had agricultural land as well as houses in the rural area in the place from where he migrated.

facts.text: He was allowed 2-1/2 acres of land in the Punjab in lieu of the agricultural land left by him in what is number Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: He was allowed 2-1/2 acres of land in the Punjab in lieu of the agricultural land left by him in what is number Pakistan.

facts.text: In addition he also left behind a house and a shop.

anchor.surface_text: In addition he also left behind a house and a shop.

facts.text: He claimed Rs. 12,000/- for the house and Rs. 8,000/- for the shop as companypensation.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed Rs. 12,000/for the house and Rs. 8,000/- for the shop as companypensation.

facts.text: The Additional Settlement Commissioner allowed his claim to the extent of Rs. 6,674/- for the house and Rs. 6,120/- for the shop, the total thus companying to Rs. 12,796/- in March 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Settlement Commissioner allowed his claim to the extent of Rs. 6,674/- for the house and Rs. 6,120/- for the shop, the total thus companying to Rs. 12,796/-. This was adjudged in March 1955.

facts.text: Thereafter, the respondent made an application to the Settlement Officer Jaipur in March 1956 for companypensation under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent made an application to the Settlement Officer Jaipur in March 1956 for companypensation under the Act.

facts.text: This claim of his was however rejected by the Assistant Settlement Officer Jaipur on the ground that it companyld number be entertained in view of r. 65 of the Rules, as he was allotted agricultural land to the extent of 2-1/2 acres.

anchor.surface_text: This claim of his was however rejected. by the Assistant Settlement Officer Jaipur on the ground that it companyld number be entertained in view of r. 65 of the Rules, as he was allotted agricultural land to the extent of 2-1/2 acres.

facts.text: The respondent then appealed to the Regional Settlement Commissioner who upheld the order of the Assistant Settlement Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then appealed to the Regional Settlement Commissioner who upheld the order of the Assistant Settlement Officer.

facts.text: Thereafter the respondent filed a writ petition before the High Court of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondent filed a writ petition before the High Court of Rajasthan and the main companytention raised by him there was that in order to determine the limit of Rs. 10,000/- provided in r. 65  2  the value of all the rural buildings left by him in Pakistan should be added, up and if the total is more than Rs. 10,000/- he is entitled to companypensation.

facts.text: The High Court accepted the contention that values of rural buildings should be added up if total more than Rs. 10,000/- and directed payment of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention has been accepted by the High Court which directed that the respondent should be paid companypensation to which he was entitled under the Rules for the rural buildings left by him the value of which companylectively was more than Rs. 1O,000/-.

facts.text: Punjab High Court Full Bench in Chanan das Mukhi v. Union of India held that rural buildings must each be of value Rs.10,000/- or more, not total.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that this question has been raised in three High Courts. The Punjab High Court, by a Full Bench decision in Chanan das Mukhi v. the Union of India  1  held that in order that a person may be entitled to companypensation for rural buildings left in Pakistan and thus take the case out of the ambit or r. 65 it is necessary that the rural buildings left by him should each be of the value of Rs. 10,000/- or Rs. 20,000/- or more, as the case may be, and that a displaced person is number entitled to companypensation if he has left more than one rural building, the value of each being less than Rs. 10,000/- or Rs. 20,000/-, though the total value of such buildings left by him may be more than Rs. 10,000/- or Rs. 20,000/-, as the ease may be.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Totaram Teckchand v. H.K. Choudhari took the same view as Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court on the other hand where a similar question was raised has taken the same view as the Rajasthan High Court in Totaram Teckchand v. H.K. Choudhari  2 .

facts.text: Inter-Dominion Conference between Governments of India and Pakistan held at Karachi between January 10 and 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: At an inter-Dominion Conference between the Governments of India and Pakistan held at Karachi between January 10 and 13, 1949, a permanent inter-Dominion Commission was set up to companysider the question of administration, sale and transfer of evacuee property in both the Dominions.

facts.text: Commission at New Delhi on March 11 and 13, 1949 recommended buildings in rural areas of value Rs.20,000/- or more as substantial, lesser as appendages to agricultural land.

anchor.surface_text: In persuance of this decision the question in respect of shops and houses in rural areas was companysidered by the Commission at New Delhi on March II and 13, 1949. It was recommended at this meeting that buildings in rural areas of value of Rs. 20,000/- or more should be companysidered to be substantial buildings and the buildings which were of lesser value than that were to be treated as appendages of agriculture land and as such were to be treated as agricultural properties.

facts.text: Rule 65 was challenged as ultra vires in Makhanlal Malhotra v. Union of India and upheld by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 65 came up for companysideration in this Court once before, when it was challenged as ultra vires on the ground that it made a discrimination between rural building for which companypensation was payable only if they were above certain value and urban buildings for which companypensation was payable, if they were of any value. The companystitutionality of r. 65 was upheld by this Court in Makhanlal Malhotra v. The Union of India  1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court held that values of multiple rural buildings cannot be added up; each must individually exceed the limit under r.65.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the view taken by the High Court is incorrect and this appeal must be allowed.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court and dismiss the writ petition. The High Court allowed number costs to the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent did not settle in the village where agricultural land was allotted.

anchor.surface_text: It seems however that he did number settle in that village and therefore companyld number get the advantage of r. 57.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 65 is in these terms Separate compensation for rural building not to be paid in certain cases. Any person to whom four acres or more of agricultural land have been allotted shall not be entitled to receive compensation separately in respect of his verified claim for any rural building the assessed value of which is less than Rs. 20,000/- Any person to whom less than four acres of agricultural land have been allotted, shall not be entitled to receive compensation separately in respect of his verified claim for any rural building the assessed value of which is less than Rs. 10,000/-

concepts.interpretation: Refers to value of each individual rural building; does not permit adding up values of multiple buildings

concepts.unlisted_label: Rule 65, Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules, 1955
concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits separate compensation for rural buildings below specified value thresholds

anchor.surface_text: Rule 57 provides that a displaced person having a verified claim in respect of agricultural land who has settled in a rural area and to whom agricultural land has been allotted, may be allotted a house in addition to such land. The rule further provides that where no house is available for allotment in the village in which the land is allotted, the allottee may be granted, if he has been allotted agricultural land not exceeding ten standard acres, a site measuring 400 square yards and a building grant of Rs.400/-...

concepts.interpretation: Provides alternative compensation (house/site grant) for rural buildings below threshold instead of separate cash compensation

holdings.text: Rule 65 does not permit adding up the values of multiple rural buildings each below the threshold to qualify for separate compensation; the assessed value limit applies to each individual rural building.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear in that background that when r. 65 speaks of any rural building the assessed value of which is less than Rs. 20,000/- or Rs. 10,000/- it speaks of each building being of that value and,does number companytemplate to talling up of the value of a number of buildings which a displaced person might have left behind and the total value of which might be Rs. 20,000/- or Rs. 10,000/-as the case may be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'any rural building' refers to each individually; supported by historical inter-Dominion agreement treating sub-Rs20,000 buildings as ag land appendages; harmonious with r.57 providing alternative house allotment/grant; agrees with Punjab Full Bench.

holdings.text: Section 13 of the General Clauses Act does not apply to read 'any rural building' (singular) in plural form, as repugnant to subject and context of Rule 65 which focuses on individual buildings.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances s. 13 of the General Clauses Act would number apply. That section specifically lays down that the singular would include the plural unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or companytext.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of Rule 65 and background scheme require considering value of each building separately, not ownership aggregation; singular term not extendable without repugnancy exception.

holdings.text: Sub-threshold rural buildings are compensated under the scheme via Rule 57 (house/site allotment in village) rather than separate cash under Chapters IV-VI or VII, subject to r.65.

anchor.surface_text: reading that with r. 65 it seems clear that in view of the inter Dominion agreement, the scheme was that where an individual building was worth more than Rs.20,000/ or Rs.10,000/- as the case may be, compensation would be payable separately under Chapters IV, V and VI of the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of rules with historical agreement; r.57 provides in-kind compensation for minor rural buildings as adjuncts to ag land; rejects no-compensation argument.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that values of rural buildings could be aggregated under r.65(2); appeal allowed, writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the view taken by the High Court is incorrect and this appeal must be allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects aggregation based on above interpretations; aligns with Punjab HC Full Bench over Rajasthan/Bombay HCs.

holdings.text: Rule 65's differentiation between rural/urban buildings and value thresholds is constitutional, as previously upheld.

The companystitutionality of r. 65 was upheld by this Court in Makhanlal Malhotra v. The Union of India

precedents.citation: Makhanlal Malhotra v. The Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: Makhanlal Malhotra v. The Union of India  1 . In that, case this Court went into the background which was responsible for the apparent discrimination between rural buildings and urban buildings. At an inter-Dominion Conference between the Governments of India and Pakistan held at Karachi between January 10 and 13, 1949, a permanent inter-Dominion Commission was set up to companysider the question of administration, sale and transfer of evacuee property in both the Dominions.

precedents.case_name: Makhanlal Malhotra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: went into the background which was responsible for the apparent discrimination between rural buildings and urban buildings; at inter-Dominion Commission meeting buildings in rural areas of value of Rs. 20,000/- or more should be companysidered to be substantial buildings and the buildings which were of lesser value than that were to be treated as appendages of agriculture land
